plugins.name: Silent Sweep
plugins.description:
Silent Sweep is your go-to Figma plugin for effortlessly managing concealed elements in your designs. This powerful tool scans your current page, revealing all hidden layers within each frame and artboard.

With its intuitive card-based interface, you can quickly identify and select hidden elements, streamlining your cleanup process.


Key Features:


  1. Instant Detection: Automatically finds all hidden layers on your current page.
  2. Organized View: Displays hidden layers grouped by their parent frames for easy navigation.
  3. Selective Cleanup: Choose which hidden layers to remove with simple checkboxes.
  4. Real-time Updates: Refreshes automatically when you switch pages or make changes.
  5. Efficient Workflow: Helps maintain clean, organized Figma files without tedious manual searching.


Whether you're polishing up a final design or inheriting a complex file, Silent Sweep helps you maintain a tidy workspace. Say goodbye to forgotten hidden layers and hello to cleaner, more manageable Figma projects. Simplify your design process and boost your productivity with Silent Sweep â€“ your personal cleanup assistant in Figma
plugins.tagline: Unveil and Tidy: Your Hidden Layer Ally

plugins.name: Collect and Rename
plugins.description:
Collect and Rename allows users to easily collect text elements from a design document, rename them, and navigate to specific layers on different pages.


Main features:


1. Collection of text elements:

- The plugin automatically collects all text elements in the document.

2. Renaming texts:

- Ability to rename text layers directly in the plugin interface.

- After renaming, text layers are updated in real time.

3. Layer navigation:

- Ability to navigate to a specific layer, even if it is on a different page of the document.



How to use the plugin:


1. Installation and launch:

- Install the "Collect and Rename" plugin from the Figma Community.

- Open your project in Figma and launch the plugin through the "Plugins" menu.

2. Text collection:

- The plugin will automatically collect all text elements from the current document and display them in the interface.

3. Renaming texts:

- In the plugin interface, you will see a list of all text layers.

- For each text element:

- "Current text" shows the current text of the layer.

- "New text" provides a field for entering new text.

- Enter the new text in the "New text" field and press "Apply" or the Enter key to confirm.

- The layer text will be updated, and you will see a notification about a successful update.

4. Navigation to layers:

- Click on the text field of the layer to automatically navigate to it in the document, even if it is on a different page.

5. Closing the plugin:

- Close the plugin when you finish your work by pressing the "Close" button in the plugin interface.
plugins.tagline: The plugin shows all text layers in a list, making it easy to replace text.

plugins.name: Fancy Figma to Bricks builder
plugins.description:
Forget doing things twice â€” design smarter by managing your variables, color palette and designs in Figma, then effortlessly transfer everything into Bricks builder with just a few clicks.


Plugin video: https://youtu.be/5_52ZX3yfGQ


Website: https://fancyframework.com/figma-plugin/


Purchase an early adopter license for 10 instances*: BUY NOW

Documentation: https://fancyframework.com/docs/

Facebook community: https://www.facebook.com/groups/fancybricks

YouTube: https://youtube.com/@fancybricks


* An instance refers to each individual installation of the software, whether on different devices or platforms. For example, if you activate the license on the desktop app and also use it on the web version, even with the same user account, it will count as two separate instances.


How it works?


Fancy Framework for Figma streamlines your workflow in three simple steps â€” from defining your design system in Figma to building real pages in Bricks. Hereâ€™s how:


Set up your design variables in Figma

Define your entire design system directly in Figma â€” colors, typography, spacing, and more. Group and name your variables for better clarity and consistency across your designs.


Export your variables and color palette to Bricks

With just a few clicks, convert your Figma variables into Bricks-compatible values. Keep your color system consistent across design and development â€” no need to manually recreate anything.


Copy from Figma, paste into Bricks

Select any Auto Layout section in Figma, copy it, and paste it directly into the Bricks editor. Supports autolayout, semantic tags, classes, grids and native Bricks elements â€” just like you designed it.


Main features

Fancy Figma to bricks builder plugin gives you everything you need to streamline your workflow: organize design variables, export color palettes, and paste fully structured sections directly into Bricks. No more duplicated effort â€” just clean, scalable, and efficient web design.


Advanced variable support

Use calc, rem, number and clamp() directly in your Figma variables for greater flexibility and control.


Auto-generate color variations

Generate transparent, darkened, and lightened versions of your colors instantly â€” no need to create them manually. Perfect for building accessible and consistent UI systems.


Export dynamic variables to Bricks

Thanks to support for clamp, calc, rem, and numeric operations, your Figma variables are ready for real-world usage inside Bricks â€” no tweaks needed.


Bricks-ready color palette export

Automatically export your color palette from Figma, linked directly to your variables â€” ready to import into Bricks and use seamlessly across your entire site.


Seamless copy-paste from Figma to Bricks

Copy any section built with Auto Layout in Figma and paste it directly into Bricks â€” layout structure, classes, and semantic tags all preserved.


Copy-Paste Features


Built for Auto Layout

By following best practices, your sections will copy perfectly into Bricks â€” layout, spacing, and hierarchy intact. Check out my free figma course: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLbc4J3wWyVcdnL9A_UA-WdE2tXRUW-I8O


Semantic HTML tag support

Your Figma sections can include semantic tags like [section], [container], [ul], [li], [h1â€“h6], [p], [span], and more. Perfect for SEO, accessibility, and clean markup.


Support for display grid

Display grid support uses (grid-x) (grid-x-x) to apply display: grid in Bricks automatically when pasting.


Class-friendly workflow

Use meaningful class names in Figma and watch them transfer seamlessly into Bricks. Combine with utility classes for maximum flexibility and control.


Bricks-native element compatibility

Paste sections that automatically map to Bricks' native elements like:

  1. Buttons
  2. Links
  3. SVG
  4. Forms
  5. Tabs
  6. Accordions
  7. Nav menu
  8. Logo
  9. Counters
  10. More will be added
plugins.tagline: The ultimate web design workflow for Bricks Builder

* An instance refers to each individual installation of the software, whether on different devices or platforms. For example, if you activate the license on the desktop app and also use it on the web version, even with the same user account, it will count as two separate instances.


How it works?


Fancy Framework for Figma streamlines your workflow in three simple steps â€” from defining your design system in Figma to building real pages in Bricks. Hereâ€™s how:


Set up your design variables in Figma

Define your entire design system directly in Figma â€” colors, typography, spacing, and more. Group and name your variables for better clarity and consistency across your designs.


Export your variables and color palette to Bricks

With just a few clicks, convert your Figma variables into Bricks-compatible values. Keep your color system consistent across design and development â€” no need to manually recreate anything.


Copy from Figma, paste into Bricks

Select any Auto Layout section in Figma, copy it, and paste it directly into the Bricks editor. Supports autolayout, semantic tags, classes, grids and native Bricks elements â€” just like you designed it.


Main features

Fancy Figma to bricks builder plugin gives you everything you need to streamline your workflow: organize design variables, export color palettes, and paste fully structured sections directly into Bricks. No more duplicated effort â€” just clean, scalable, and efficient web design.


Advanced variable support

Use calc, rem, number and clamp() directly in your Figma variables for greater flexibility and control.


Auto-generate color variations

Generate transparent, darkened, and lightened versions of your colors instantly â€” no need to create them manually. Perfect for building accessible and consistent UI systems.


Export dynamic variables to Bricks

Thanks to support for clamp, calc, rem, and numeric operations, your Figma variables are ready for real-world usage inside Bricks â€” no tweaks needed.


Bricks-ready color palette export

Automatically export your color palette from Figma, linked directly to your variables â€” ready to import into Bricks and use seamlessly across your entire site.


Seamless copy-paste from Figma to Bricks

Copy any section built with Auto Layout in Figma and paste it directly into Bricks â€” layout structure, classes, and semantic tags all preserved.


Copy-Paste Features


Built for Auto Layout

By following best practices, your sections will copy perfectly into Bricks â€” layout, spacing, and hierarchy intact. Check out my free figma course: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLbc4J3wWyVcdnL9A_UA-WdE2tXRUW-I8O


Semantic HTML tag support

Your Figma sections can include semantic tags like [section], [container], [ul], [li], [h1â€“h6], [p], [span], and more. Perfect for SEO, accessibility, and clean markup.


Support for display grid

Display grid support uses (grid-x) (grid-x-x) to apply display: grid in Bricks automatically when pasting.


Class-friendly workflow

Use meaningful class names in Figma and watch them transfer seamlessly into Bricks. Combine with utility classes for maximum flexibility and control.


Bricks-native element compatibility

Paste sections that automatically map to Bricks' native elements like:

  1. Buttons
  2. Links
  3. SVG
  4. Forms
  5. Tabs
  6. Accordions
  7. Nav menu
  8. Logo
  9. Counters
  10. More will be added

[Fix] Counter hidden elements in component

[Fix] Form hidden elements in component
[Fix] Normalize "ul" padding and margin added by Bricks.

plugins.name: Countastic
plugins.description:
Countastic is the ultimate Figma calculator plugin, built to help product designers create data-centric products and screens faster and more efficiently.


Add, subtract, calculate averages and percentages automatically and use them in your designs with a single click, making the data on screen believable and relevant to your customers, stakeholders and usability test participants.


A must have for any designer sweating the details of data tables, sales and analytics dashboards, finance or e-commerce products.


Get the license

(7 day trial, team discounts available)


Get started

Countastic performs calculations on objects selected in your Figma file, showing you results you can copy or place on the canvas with a single click.


Open Countastic and:

  1. Select two or more text objects in your Figma file
  2. See the sum, difference, average and percentage difference of the selected objects.
  3. Click the result of a calculation to copy to clipboard
  4. Click the â€œPlaceâ€ button beside the calculation to add the result to the canvas


Countastic works with:

  1. Currencies (including US, UK and European separator and decimal point styles)
  2. Units of measure
  3. Any numerical values containing prefixes or suffixes


Countastic helps you calculate:

  1. Sums
  2. Differences
  3. Averages
  4. Percentage differences (between 2 objects only)


Get the license

(7 day trial, team discounts available)


Questions and feedback

Countastic requires no setup, allowing you to hit the ground running and use relevant, real-looking data in your designs.


If you have feedback about Countastic or want to share an idea or a feature request, drop me a line on X, Bluesky or Threads.

Get actionable insights to improve usability, accessibility, and visual consistencyâ€”all without needing an API key!

  1. Select an area: Choose a single frame or an entire flow with multiple frames.

plugins.name: MAPPE â€” Mini map for Figma
plugins.description:
The figma area (if we take the entire canvas) is 262,000 x 262,000 pixels. If there are few screens and they are small, you do not think about the actual canvas size. But when there are a lot of layouts, at some point you run into the edge of the canvas. At this point, you understand that it becomes impossible to navigate in figma.


MAPPE makes navigation in big files easier. The plugin shows where are you exactly on the canvas.

You can either teach each stakeholder to hide annotations via shortcut, or you need to copy the mocks to a new page/file, and then manually remove dozens/hundreds of annotations...


No longer!


With the Annotations busterâ„¢ plugin you can clean up your stakeholder review mockups in one go.


Video demo -> https://youtu.be/tjQdLxtF01o


If you like this plugin, consider sharing on the socials or buying me an oat-milk latte â†’ https://www.buymeacoffee.com/menosketiago

plugins.name: WCAG 2.2 Text Resize Checker (SC 1.4.4) for Design Systems
plugins.description:
The WCAG 2.2 Text Resize Checker plugin designed to help you ensure that your design system components comply with SC 1.4.4: Resize Text (Level AA). This plugin helps verify that all text elements within your Figma designs behave appropriately when resized to 200% of their original size.


Key Features:

  1. 200% Text Resize: Duplicates the selected element and automatically applies 200% text resize to all text layers of the selected element.
  2. All Component Checking: Works with text layers, groups, frames, auto-layout, and any other elements.
  3. Line Height Adjustments: Allows you to update the line height according to the new size, or ignore it.
plugins.tagline: Check the behavior of your design system components according to the 200% text resize (WCAG 2.2)

plugins.name: IconBridge â€“ Automated Icon Handoff from Figma to GitHub
plugins.description:
A powerful Figma plugin that automates icon exports, optimizes assets, and pushes them directly to GitHubâ€”seamlessly integrating design and development. IconBridge eliminates manual file handling, ensuring every icon is correctly formatted, optimized, and instantly available for development.



âœ¨ Key Features


  1. Optimized Icon Export â€“ Export icons directly from Figma with automatic light/dark version generation for multi-colored icons.
  2. Seamless GitHub Integration â€“ Push icons directly from Figma to GitHub, with automated organization and validation.
  3. Automated Pull Request Creation â€“ IconBridge commits and opens a GitHub PR automatically, streamlining the handoff process.
  4. Secure Repository Access â€“ Uses GitHub authentication to ensure private and controlled icon handoff.




ğŸš€ How to Use


Quick & Optimized Icon Export

  1. Select your icons in Figma.
  2. Click â€œExport Iconsâ€ on the home screen.
  3. IconBridge automatically optimizes each icon, ensuring clean, lightweight SVGs.
  4. Click â€œSaveâ€ to download optimized icons directly to your device.


Automated Handoff to GitHub

  1. Select your icons in Figma.
  2. Click â€œExport to GitHubâ€ to begin the automation.
  3. IconBridge optimizes and validates each icon before uploading.
  4. Automatically organizes icons in the correct repository folder.
  5. Creates a pull request automatically, ready for developer review.




ğŸ› ï¸ What Youâ€™ll Need

  1. A Figma project with icons.
  2. A GitHub repository for automated exports.




ğŸ”’ Secure & Seamless Workflow

IconBridge ensures a secure, efficient, and automated handoff process:


  1. Direct Figma-to-GitHub integrationâ€”no external storage needed.
  2. Authentication with GitHub to keep your repository secure.
  3. Fully automated workflowâ€”eliminating manual exports, uploads, and PR creation.


ğŸš€ Forget tedious icon managementâ€”let IconBridge automate everything from Figma to production!

plugins.name: MagicText
plugins.description:
A powerful Figma plugin designed to streamline your workflow by recognizing, transforming, and cleaning up text layers in seconds. Whether you're extracting text from images, converting case styles, or refining typography, this tool enhances productivity and ensures design consistency with just a few clicks.


How It Works:


1. Text Recognition

Use the built-in text recognize to quickly extract text from image layers. Simply select an image layer, choose the desired language, and launch text recognition â€“ the plugin will automatically create a new text layer with the extracted content.

Supported Languages: MagicText supports a wide range of languages: English, Chinese, Ukrainian, Spanish, German, French, Japanese, Korean, Arabic, Portuguese, Italian, Bulgarian, Greek, Hebrew, Hindi, Turkish and more.


2. Text Transformation:

Easily change the case of your text with a single click:

  1. Title Case: Capitalize the first letter of each word.
  2. Sentence Case: Capitalize only the first letter of each sentence.
  3. UPPERCASE & lowercase: Convert your text to all uppercase or all lowercase letters.


3. Text Manipulation:

Seamlessly merge multiple text layers into one or split a single text layer into individual sentences for easier editing.


4. Style Cleanup:

  1. Remove Hyperlinks: Automatically strip out hyperlinks from your text.
  2. Remove All Styles: Reset text and color styles, reverting your text to a clean, default appearance.


5. Character Counter:

Instantly see the number of characters, sentences, and words in your selected text layers for precise text management.


Key Features:

  1. Image-Based Text Recognition: Extract text from images with support for multiple languages.
  2. Case Conversion Options: Transform text to sentence case, title case, UPPERCASE, or lowercase in just a few clicks.
  3. Text Layer Manipulation: Merge and split text layers effortlessly to suit your workflow.
  4. Style Reset: Remove hyperlinks and reset text formatting to maintain consistency in your designs.
  5. Real-Time Character Counting: Keep track of characters, sentences, and words in real time.


Who Is It For?

MagicText is designed for Figma designers who want to streamline their text formatting and editing process. By automating repetitive tasks and offering powerful text transformation tools, MagicText allows you to focus more on creative design and less on manual text adjustments.


Feedback & Future Updates

Welcome your professional insights and suggestions for improvements. Your feedback is invaluable and will be carefully reviewed to guide future updates. Please share your ideas and help us enhance MagicText. Leave your feedback here.
plugins.tagline: Recognize, transform, and clean text layers instantlyâ€”enhancing productivity and consistency.

plugins.name: The Settler â€” localiser for external (or missing) alias variables
plugins.description:
(Ğ ÑƒÑÑĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ Ğ²Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ·Ñƒ ğŸ‘‡)

en:

This plugin localises all alias variables that refer to missing base variables (those located in external files or simply deleted)

ğŸ¦ Video demonstration: https://youtu.be/f9Ofv7lB-Lk


Why is this a problem?! Figma doesn't care about these links, it doesn't transfer them to the new file, but leaves the links to the companion variables (base/master variables) in the old file. And this isn't what you expect when you copy variables :)


In simple words, what the plugin does:

  1. It looks for alias variables that have a reference to base variables that didn't make it to this file (either left in another file or simply missing)
  2. Creates copies of such variables in this file
  3. Rebinds the alias variable, changing the reference from the external master variable (base variable) to the newly created local one


Works for variables of all types:

  1. color,
  2. text,
  3. boolean,
  4. numeric

It should work with multiple mods, but I haven't tested this part.

The Figma plugin â€œText to Frame Nameâ€ is a handy tool that allows you to replace selected text with the name of the highest-level frame it belongs to, all at once. This is particularly useful for page numbers in presentation materials or proposals. For example, you can set frame names with sequential numbers like â€œ01,â€ â€œ02,â€ and â€œ03,â€ place temporary text (e.g., â€œ00â€) on each page, select all the text, and run this plugin to complete page numbering. Even if you reorder or add pages, you can easily reset the numbers by simply modifying the frame names. This eliminates the need for manual number adjustments, significantly improving workflow efficiency.

plugins.name: Rename From Sublayer
plugins.description:
Rename from sublayers simplifies the process of renaming groups in Figma by automatically detecting image, text or shape layers within selected groups.


You can choose between five modes: image detection, text layer, Rectangle layer, ellipse layer and symbols detection.

Additionally, you can opt to rename all child groups within the hierarchy or just the top-level group, giving you full control over your naming conventions.


Key Features:

  1. Image, Text, Shape Detection: Automatically rename groups based on image names, text names, rectangle names, ellipse names and symbols.
  2. Selective Renaming: Choose to rename just the highest-level group or all nested child groups.
  3. User-Friendly Interface: Simple and intuitive UI to quickly toggle between options.


Whether you're managing large design systems or working on a small project, Rename from sublayers helps keep your layers organized and your workflow efficient.
plugins.tagline: Effortlessly rename groups by image, text or shape layers.

Ripplix â€” friction-free design hand-off with motion

Skip the time-consuming prototypes and pin real-world interactions straight onto your Figma file.

Ripplix already has a curated library of 1 500 + micro-interactions from 300 + live apps & sites into an easy-to-search sidebar. One click drops a comment tag on the exact UI element (button, card, tabâ€¦) and links to a full-screen preview on ripplix.com so developers instantly see how it should feelâ€”timing, easing, choreography and all.


Why youâ€™ll use it every hand-off

  1. Contextual pins â€“ Each animation is attached as a Figma comment on the layer you select, so engineers donâ€™t have to hunt for it.
  2. Real-app reference â€“ Every clip comes from production UIs, giving devs proven motion patterns instead of speculative mocks.
  3. Search that speaks UX â€“ Filter by platform (Web, iOS, Android, Watch), pattern (hover, dropdown, empty stateâ€¦), industry or keyword.
  4. One-click preview â€“ Comment contains a â€œView on Ripplixâ€ link â†’ opens the HD interaction with playback controls, frame counter and downloadable Lottie/CSS snippets.
  5. Zero bloat â€“ Nothing is embedded in the Figma file except a tiny thumbnail + link, so your files stay light.


Typical Workflow

  3. Preview candidates; click Add to Figma.
  4. A comment tag appears on your layer, click upon you can preview the motion.

plugins.name: Smart Selection
plugins.description:
Smart Selection is a powerful tool for designers that allows flexible filtering of elements based on multiple parameters: dimensions, names, types, properties, and even child element content.


The plugin enables you to:

  1. Filter elements by exact values, ranges, and regular expressions
  2. Find objects with specific child elements
  3. Save, load, and combine sets of selected elements
  4. Export and import selection sets to share between files and teams
  5. Use an intuitive interface with convenient filters


Essential for working with complex designs when you need to quickly find elements with specific characteristics â€” save time on routine selection tasks and start working more efficiently.

plugins.name: AutoFrame
plugins.description:
AutoFrame: Connect Airtable Data to Your Figma Designs


Bridge the gap between your data and your designs! Autoframe allows you to seamlessly connect your Airtable bases directly to Figma, automating the creation and synchronization of design elements.


Stop manually copying and pasting data. With Autoframe, you can generate perfectly structured Figma frames populated with real content from your Airtable views, saving you time and reducing errors.


Key Features:

  1. Secure Airtable Connection: Easily connect your Airtable account using a secure OAuth 2.0 flow.
  2. Automated Frame Generation: Select an Airtable Base, Table, and View, and instantly generate Figma frames for each record.
  3. Data-Driven Content: Choose specific Airtable fields to populate text layers within your frames, ensuring your designs reflect your actual data.
  4. Custom Frame Naming: Designate an Airtable field to automatically name your generated frames.
  5. Dynamic Frame Sizing: Optionally add a "Dimensions" field (e.g., 300x500) in your Airtable view to automatically set the width and height of corresponding Figma frames.
  6. Flexible Layout: Control the arrangement of generated frames by specifying the number of columns.
  7. Figma to Airtable: Push text edits or frame name changes made in Figma back to your Airtable base.
  8. Airtable to Figma: Pull the latest data from Airtable to update your existing generated frames without needing to regenerate everything.
  9. Secure Login: Protects access via an Email + One-Time Passcode (OTP) verification system.


How It Works:

  1. Connect: Log in and securely connect your Airtable account.
  2. Select: Choose your Airtable Base, Table, View, and the fields you want to use for frame names and content.
  3. Generate: Click "Generate Frames" to automatically create frames on your Figma canvas populated with your data.
  4. Sync: Use the "Sync Changes to Airtable" or "Sync From Airtable" buttons to keep your designs and data aligned.


Ideal For:

  1. Data-driven design workflows
  2. Managing dynamic content within designs (e.g., user profiles, product cards)
  3. Populating components for design systems
  4. Quickly visualizing data structures from Airtable
  5. Anyone looking to streamline their design process by integrating directly with Airtable.


Get started with AutoFrame today and bring your Airtable data to life in Figma!
plugins.tagline: Autoframe: The Bridge Between Airtable and Figma.

  4. Custom Frame Naming: Designate an Airtable field to automatically name your generated frames.
  5. Dynamic Frame Sizing: Optionally add a "Dimensions" field (e.g., 300x500) in your Airtable view to automatically set the width and height of corresponding Figma frames.
  6. Flexible Layout: Control the arrangement of generated frames by specifying the number of columns.
  7. Figma to Airtable: Push text edits or frame name changes made in Figma back to your Airtable base.
  8. Airtable to Figma: Pull the latest data from Airtable to update your existing generated frames without needing to regenerate everything.
  9. Secure Login: Protects access via an Email + One-Time Passcode (OTP) verification system.


How It Works:

  1. Connect: Log in and securely connect your Airtable account.
  2. Select: Choose your Airtable Base, Table, View, and the fields you want to use for frame names and content.
  3. Generate: Click "Generate Frames" to automatically create frames on your Figma canvas populated with your data.
  4. Sync: Use the "Sync Changes to Airtable" or "Sync From Airtable" buttons to keep your designs and data aligned.


Ideal For:

  1. Data-driven design workflows
  2. Managing dynamic content within designs (e.g., user profiles, product cards)
  3. Populating components for design systems
  4. Quickly visualizing data structures from Airtable
  5. Anyone looking to streamline their design process by integrating directly with Airtable.


Get started with AutoFrame today and bring your Airtable data to life in Figma!
133337.tagline: Autoframe: The Bridge Between Airtable and Figma.

plugins.name: Figma to inspecta - compare design to web
plugins.description:
This Figma plugin works with inspecta Chrome extension, enhancing your design QA workflow.


Download the Chrome extension: inspecta - Visual QA and CSS editor


How to use the Figma to Inspecta plugin

  1. Install the plugin: Add the plugin to your Figma workspace.
  2. Copy color styles and variables
  3. Paste and compare in Inspecta:
  4. Open your webpage.
  5. Launch the Inspecta Chrome extension.
  6. Click "Paste & Compare Figma colors" to analyze and match colors between Figma and your live webpage.
plugins.tagline: Auto compare Figma color styles and variables with your webpage colors

plugins.name: Figma To GFX
plugins.description: The FTAGFX Plugin allows users to turn Figma Objects into GFX objects! The goal is to help with faster prototyping on boards with (touch)Screens.
